html:
May Shows No Softening in Shelter Inflation

The good news on housing is that inflation in the sector remained steady last month. That’s the bad news as well.

The index for shelter rose 0.3% in May for the second consecutive month, representing the primary factor in the monthly price increase for all items, at 0.1%, the BLS reported. Housing inflation measured 3.9% for the 12 months ending May.

Rents increased 0.2% month over month in May, a bit slower than April’s 0.3% advance. Homeowners saw their housing costs, as measured by the index for owners' equivalent rent, up 0.3% last month. That is also a slowdown from the 0.4% monthly rate in April.
